head.title: Hybrid Thin-Film Encapsulation for All-Solid-State Thin-Film Batteries | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Hybrid Thin-Film Encapsulation for All-Solid-State Thin-Film Batteries

All-solid-state thin-film batteries have been actively investigated as a power source for various microdevices. However, insufficient research has been conducted on thin-film encapsulation, which is an essential element of these batteries as solid electrolytes and Li anodes are vulnerable to moisture in the atmosphere. In this study, a hybrid thin-film encapsulation structure of hybrid SiOy/SiNxOy/a-SiNx:H/Parylene is suggested and investigated. The water-vapor transmission rate of hybrid thin-film encapsulation is estimated to be 4.9 × 10–3 g m–2·day–1, a value that is applicable to batteries as well as flexible solar cells, thin-film transistor liquid-crystal display, and E-papers. As a result of hybrid thin-film encapsulation, it is confirmed that the all-solid-state thin-film batteries are stable even after 100 charge/discharge cycles in the air atmosphere for 30 days and present a Coulombic efficiency of 99.8% even after 100 cycles in the air atmosphere. These results demonstrate that the thin-film encapsulation structure of hybrid SiOy/SiNxOy/a-SiNx:H/Parylene can be employed in thin-film batteries while retaining long-term stability.

div.p:
All-solid-state thin-film batteries have been actively investigated as a power source for various microdevices. However, insufficient research has been conducted on thin-film encapsulation, which is an essential element of these batteries as solid electrolytes and Li anodes are vulnerable to moisture in the atmosphere. In this study, a hybrid thin-film encapsulation structure of hybrid SiO
y
/SiN
x
O
y
/
a
-SiN
x
:H/Parylene is suggested and investigated. The water-vapor transmission rate of hybrid thin-film encapsulation is estimated to be 4.9 × 10
–3
g m
–2
·day
–1
, a value that is applicable to batteries as well as flexible solar cells, thin-film transistor liquid-crystal display, and E-papers. As a result of hybrid thin-film encapsulation, it is confirmed that the all-solid-state thin-film batteries are stable even after 100 charge/discharge cycles in the air atmosphere for 30 days and present a Coulombic efficiency of 99.8% even after 100 cycles in the air atmosphere. These results demonstrate that the thin-film encapsulation structure of hybrid SiO
y
/SiN
x
O

/
a
-SiN
x
:H/Parylene can be employed in thin-film batteries while retaining long-term stability.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Recently, all-solid-state batteries have been actively studied in order for them to be applied to electric vehicles and health monitoring devices,
(1−3)
as they are more stable than liquid electrolytes, which have a risk of explosion.

In addition, the energy and power density of the battery are high when the battery is compactly fabricated. The thin-film battery, which is a type of all-solid-state battery, was initially reported by Bates et al.
(4)
It is composed of a substrate, cathode, solid electrolyte, anode, and current collector. These batteries have several advantages, such as a coming in a variety of shapes and sizes, thermal stability, long life cycles, high volumetric energy densities, embedding/implanting possibilities, and safety,
(5−7)
making them suitable power storage devices for vehicles, health monitors, microsensors, and so on.
(8)
However, as reported in the previous literature, the solid electrolyte is not stable in the atmosphere. Lithium phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON), which is widely used as a solid electrolyte, is vulnerable to moisture in the atmosphere.
(9−12)
In addition, some thin-film batteries use Li metal as the anode to increase energy density. Therefore, all-solid-state thin-film batteries (ASSTFBs) require encapsulation. However, the research on encapsulation of thin-film batteries is still insufficient. Thus far, there have been reports on metal housing, pouches, and so on,
(13,14)
which have been used in commercialized batteries and confirmed to be highly resilient against oxygen and moisture in the atmosphere. However, because the weight of the packing thickness is higher than that of the device itself, these methods reduce the energy density of thin-film batteries. Thus, to overcome those disadvantages of conventional bulk packaging, thin-film encapsulation (TFE) will be quite suitable for thin-film batteries. TFE has been actively studied for achieving high barrier performance to water and oxygen permeation in OLEDs and displays.
(15−17)
For thin-film batteries, there have been multiple reports on multilayer TFE such as metal/nitride thin film/metal, SiO
2
/Si
3
N
4
/Parylene, epoxy/Si
3
N
4
/LiPON/LiPO, and Al
2
O
3
/thin glass/PDMS.
(18−22)
However, the long-term stability of thin-film batteries with encapsulation has not been still reliably implemented.

Thus, we conducted a study on the process development and characteristics of the
a
-SiN
x
:H/SiN
x
O
y
/hybrid SiO
y
(ASH) ultrahigh multibarrier film in advance and confirmed the excellent barrier characteristics of a WVTR value of 2 × 10
–6
g/m
2
·day.
(23)
In this study, we developed a unique construction of the
a
-SiN
x
:H/SiN
x
O
y
/hybrid SiO
y
/Parylene (ASH/Parylene) multilayer thin film to employ as the hybrid TEF in ASSTFBs.
Figure
1
shows the schematic of encapsulated ASSTFBs.
Figure
1
a,b presents the schematics of TFE/ASSTFBs and cross section, respectively. Parylene was first deposited by a thermal evaporator. Subsequently, the amorphous hydrogenated silicon nitride (
a
-SiN
x
:H) film with 300–400 nm thickness was deposited on the Parylene thin film by plasma-assisted chemical vapor deposition (PECVD). The organically modified silica (ORMOSIL) sol was coated on an
a
-SiN
x
:H thin film and post-heat-treated at 120 °C for 10 h in an oven; it was converted into the hybrid SiO
y
thin film, and the SiN
x
O
y
thin film with approximately 4 nm thickness was simultaneously formed at the interface between the
a
-SiN
x
:H thin film and the hybrid SiO
y
thin film through heat treatment. The thicknesses of the Parylene thin film and ASH were approximately 2.4 and 1.2 μm, respectively. In the hybrid TFE, the intermediate SiN
x
O
y
thin film has a very high density of 3.32 g cm
–3
(22)
and plays a crucial role in preventing oxygen and moisture penetration; nonetheless, deposition of the Parylene thin film is also a prerequisition step for planarization of surface morphology and protection of the thin-film battery prior to deposition of
a
-SiN
x
:H processed under a chemically active plasma mixture of SiH
4
as well as NH
3
radicals. ASSTFBs with hybrid TFE were accurately tested for 30 days in the atmosphere to evaluate their stability and performance.

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic of encapsulated ASSTFBs. (a) Schematic diagram of TFE/ASSTFBs and (b) cross-sectional illustration.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The TFE was fabricated on a thin-film solid electrolyte for ionic conductivity measurement. The thin-film electrolyte consists of the LiPON thin-film electrolyte and Pt metal electrode.
Figure
2
shows the cross-sectional image of the thin-film encapsulation.
Figure
2
a shows an image obtained using a field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM). It was difficult to distinguish each layer. Therefore, the TFE was confirmed using a backscatter electron detector (
Figure
2
b), and each composition layer was clearly separated from both EDS (
Figure
2
c) and HRTEM (
Figure
2
d). The Parylene layer thickness is measured to be approximately 2.4 μm. The total thickness of the ASH thin film is 1.2 μm on the Parylene layer. It is observed that a dense interfacial SiN
x
O
y
layer exists at the interface between the
a
-SiN
x
:H films and hybrid SiO
y
film. The mechanism of the formation of SiN
x
O
y
is discussed as follows.
(23)
In the first step, the hydroxyl group is formed on the
a
-SiN
x
:H surface treated with oxygen plasma through hydrogen bonding. Hydrolysis of the ORMOSIL sol induces the formation of hydroxyl groups on the surface of hybrid SiO
y
, which reacts with hydroxyl groups on the
a
-SiN
x
:H. At the second step, in the annealing process, the SiN
x
O
y
layer is formed by a condensation reaction between the hybrid SiO
y
and
a
-SiN
x
:H. It can be inferred that the SiN
x
O
y
layer is denser than hybrid SiO
y
and
a
-SiN
x
:H due to abundant hydrogen of water molecules formed by hydrogen bonds and polymer chains derived from hybrid SiO
y
. In the critical annealing process over 10 h, the water molecules and polymer chain from SiN
x
O
y
are diffused out.
(23)

div.p: Figure 2. Scanning electron microscopy images of the thin-film encapsulation observed by (a) FE-SEM and (b) FE-SEM backscatter electron detector. (c) EDS mapping of Si, O, N, and C elements and (d) cross-sectional HR-TEM images of ASH film.

div.div:
To verify the barrier characteristics of the Parylene layer and ASH film, bare PET, Parylene/bare PET, and ASH/Parylene/bare PET films were prepared and corresponding WVTR values were measured using the MOCON Permatran W-700 and Aquatran 2. As shown in
Figure
3
, the WVTR values of the bare PET, Parylene/bare PET, and ASH/Parylene/bare PET are 4.76, 4.06, and 4.9 × 10
–3
g m
–2
·day
–1
, respectively. It can be seen that the WVTR value of the Parylene layer is similar to that of the bare PET, while the ASH/Parylene film shows a lowest WVTR value of 4.9 × 10
–3
g m
–2
·day
–1
, which implies that the additional ASH layer will play an important role on lowering the WVTR. According to
Figure S1
, the WVTRs of single
a
-SiN
x
:H/PET and hybrid SiO
y
/PET layer were measured as 8.5 × 10
–2
and 4.9 g m
–2
·day
–1
, respectively. Therefore, it is clearly shown that not only
a
-SiN
x
:H but also the dense SiN
x
O
y
layer between the
a
-SiN
x
:H and hybrid SiO
y
layers effectively passivates the leakage channels and acts as a decoupling layer that combines with the formation of tortuous paths, which appear to elongate the water molecular diffusion length.

div.p: Figure 3. WVTR values of the bare PET, bare Parylene/PET, and bare ASH/Parylene/PET.

div.div:
Figure
4
shows the EIS of LiPON. The LiPON was prepared as four types of samples: LiPON, Parylene/LiPON, ASH/LiPON, and ASH/Parylene/LiPON. All samples were kept in an air atmosphere (35% RH, 22 °C), and the change was measured by EIS.
Figure
4
a exhibits the change of charge transfer impedance with time in the air atmosphere for as-deposited LiPON. The initial charge transfer impedance as 2.4 kΩ and increased up to 655.9 kΩ after 30 days. This confirms that the resistance of the interface increased through simulation. As shown in the equivalent circuit (
Table S1
), the interface resistance increased. Although this did not significantly exceed the value reported by Nimisha et al.,
(11)
the result is sufficient to prove that LiPON itself is vulnerable to the atmosphere and agrees with the previous result reported by Nagata and Nanno on the vulnerability LiPON to humidity.
(12)
Therefore, evidently, encapsulation is required for the LiPON electrolyte. The change in ionic conductivity with time for Parylene/LiPON is shown in
Figure
4
b. The change in charge transfer impedance caused by as-Parylene deposition was, however, not significant. The initial charge transfer impedance was 2.5 kΩ; however, it increased to 278.2 kΩ after 30 days. As shown in
Figure
3
, the TFE of Parylene solely was found to be ineffective and was due to a poor WVTR.
Figure
4
c exhibits the change in charge transfer impedance with time for ASH/LiPON in the air atmosphere. A slight change in EIS by deposition of ASH was observed. Because TFE uses ASH, a semicircle was observed at low frequency, suggesting that it was due to the interface. The initial charge transfer impedance was 4.8 kΩ, which was maintained for 30 days. The change in ionic conductivity in the air atmosphere for ASH/Parylene/LiPON is shown in
Figure
4
d, although the change in EIS by depositing ASH cannot be seen. It is considered that the Parylene layer acts as a buffer layer that restricts the formation of the interface generated during ASH deposition processing. The initial charge transfer impedance was 3.1 kΩ, and almost no change was observed in it for 30 days. Among the four samples, the ASH/Parylene/LiPON one shows the most stable behavior. Generally, for the thin film, defects such as pinholes are formed during deposition. These pinholes form the interfaces by oxidizing the lithium electrode or reacting with a solid electrolyte during dipcoating with the ORMOSIL sol. It has been reported that LiPON, a solid electrolyte, is very vulnerable to moisture. Therefore, from
Figure
4
c, one can observe dipcoating without Parylene forming the interface by reacting with moisture of the ORMOSIL sol. However, for
Figure
4
d, the sample was protected during dipcoating because it was coated with Parylene, thus showing a stable encapsulation property for 8 h. In other words, Parylene is an effective and process-suitable protective film that inhibits the interface generation during the ASH deposition process. The initial ionic conductivity of as-deposited LiPON is 1.2 × 10
–6
S cm
–1
, which is similarly kept to be 1.03 × 10
–6
S cm
–1
even after depositing ASH/Parylene TFE. In addition, the ionic conductivity of ASH/Parylene/LiPON is invariably maintained at 1.01 × 10
–6
S cm
–1
even after 30 days. Moreover, it is revealed that direct deposition of ASH on ASSTFBs without a Parylene buffer layer increases the charge transfer impedance invoked by the unsmooth interface. The larger charge transfer impedance of the LiPON than that of the ASSTFBs is because the measured area of the LiPON is smaller than that of the ASSTFBs.

div.p: Figure 4. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) of the solid electrolyte: (a) LiPON without TFE, (b) Parylene/LiPON, (c) ASH/LiPON, and (d) ASH/Parylene/LiPON. (e) The equivalent circuit model for LiPON solid electrolyte.

div.div:
Figure
5
shows the ASSTFBs with/without TFE exposure to an air atmosphere during the oxidation process.
Figure
5
a shows the as-fabricated ASSTFBs without TFE. In that ASSTFBs, Li oxidation directly occurs because of the lack of TFE and makes the anode current collector disconnected from the Li metal anode.
Figure
5
b shows Parylene/ASSTFBs; for this case of TFE, oxidation began after 10 h in an air atmosphere and eventually completes after approximately 27 h, and the anode current collector was fully disconnected from the Li metal anode.
Figure
5
c shows ASH/ASSTFBs for which oxidation seems to be initiated by the ORMOSIL sol during the dipcoating.
Figure
5
c shows a photograph taken immediately after annealing, and it was confirmed that the entire battery was oxidized during ASH TFE processing; the battery was also partially exfoliated. Therefore, it was concluded that direct deposition of ASH is not suitable for TFE on ASSTFBs.
Figure
5
d shows ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs; any oxidation in neither ASSTFBs by ORMOIL nor the Li metal even after heat treatment was observed. Additionally, it is noticeable that the ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs was not oxidized in the air atmosphere even after 1 day, unlike other samples. Electrochemical analysis was performed to confirm its TFE effects. It is difficult that the surfaces of ASH and ASH/Parylene are confirmed by SEM because it is hard to confirm oxidation inside thin-film encapsulation using SEM, as shown in
Figure S2
. Therefore, in this study, it is confirmed how long has it protected from oxidation electrochemically.

div.p: Figure 5. ASSTFBs exposure to air atmosphere until oxidation: (a) ASSTFBs without TFE, (b) Parylene/ASSTFBs, (c) ASH/ASSTFBs, and (d) ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs.

div.div:
Figure
6
shows a charge–discharge graph with time to confirm the time-related potential of ASSTFBs in an air atmosphere.
Figure
6
a shows the ASSTFB results without TFE. After 10 min of charging, the potential rapidly increased because of anode oxidation, and it then became an open circuit.
Figure
6
b shows the Parylene/ASSTFBs result. It was charged normally for approximately 6 h. For LiFePO
4
, the plateau was observed at 3.4 V; however, the Li oxidation occurred during discharge and the flux was observed at 3.4 V. In the second cycle, the voltage plateau was not observed at 3.4 V, and the voltage rapidly increased and decreased. The voltage flux increased further because of the evolution of the Li oxidation during the cycle. The cycle properties could not be investigated owing to the complete Li oxidation. For ASH/ASSTFBs, the electrochemical property could not be analyzed because the battery was damaged immediately after deposition of TFE.
Figure
6
c presents the ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs results. Li anode oxidation was not observed, as confirmed in
Figure
5
d. In 30 h, more than three charge/discharge cycles were performed. The charge/discharge cycles of all samples were performed at a 0.2 C rate, and thus, a specific capacity could be compared as a function of time. During the first cycle, the charging time and specific capacity of Parylene/ASSTFBs were similar to those of ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs. Therefore, it was assumed that there is no negative effect during the ASH process after Parylene deposition. It was confirmed that ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs provide long-term stability in an air atmosphere.

div.p: Figure 6. Charge–discharge graph with time: (a) as-fabricated ASSTFBs without TFE, (b) Parylene/ASSTFBs, and (c) ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs.

div.div:
Figure
7
shows the electrochemical property of ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs. The charge/discharge was performed at a 0.2 C rate and the voltage in a range of 3–4 V.
Figure
7
a presents the charge–discharge graph of the 1st, 2nd, 10th, 50th, and 100th cycles for ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs. The initial capacity of ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs is 7.5 μAh cm
–2
μm
–1
. The Coulombic efficiency is 64.8%, which is a relatively low value. This would be caused by the irreversible capacity due to the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) formation and interfacial impedance. There is no change in the discharge capacity until the second cycle. After the 10th cycle, the discharge capacity increases to 9.0 μAh cm
–2
μm
–1
. The discharge capacities of the 50th and 100th cycles were higher than that of the 10th cycle; the discharge capacity of the 50th cycle was 9.9 μAh cm
–2
μm
–1
, which is similar to that of 100th cycle.
Figure
7
b shows the cycle performance. Although the Coulombic efficiency at the first cycle is as low as 64.8%, it increased as the number of cycles increased. The Coulombic efficiency was 95.8% at the 20th cycle. Finally, a Coulombic efficiency of 99.8% and stable charge–discharge performance were observed at the 100th cycle. A Coulombic efficiency of 99% indicates highly stable cycle properties, thus confirming the cycle performance, which is the advantage of an all-solid-state battery.
Figure
7
c shows the result of EIS for ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs. The charge transfer impedance is 420 Ω after one cycle; it increased to 450 Ω after two cycles but decreased to 350 Ω after 10 cycles and was maintained nearly at 370 Ω until after 100 cycles. The charge transfer impedance is relatively high during the first and second cycles because of the interfacial resistance. If the adhesion between the electrode and electrolyte is poor, the Li transfer impedance can be increased. The interfacial resistance is caused by micropores or poor interfacial adhesion during the ASSTFB fabrication process. However, both the mass transfer and charge transfer improve significantly after 10 cycles. We propose that this is because the interfacial impedance decreases as lithium conduction paths are established on the interface during cycling. Although the charge transfer impedance after 10 cycles increased only by 5% until 100 cycles, it was still lower than the initial charge transfer impedance. Indeed, the impedance and limited ionic conductivity at the solid electrolyte-electrode interfaces are critical issues for achieving solid-state batteries. Studies to improve interfacial impedance are being conducted by various research groups. It has been demonstrated that the interfacial resistance can be significantly improved by using an interfacial adhesion layer such as Al
2
O
3
thin film deposited by ALD, as reported by Han et al.
(24)

div.p: Figure 7. (a) Charge–discharge graph, (b) cycle property, and (c) EIS of ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
In this study, hybrid TFE was demonstrated on ASSTFBs. The experiment was carried out under three TFE conditions: Parylene, ASH, and ASH/Parylene. ASH/Parylene showed the best performance in terms of TFE properties; the WVTR of ASH/Parylene was found to be 4.9 × 10
–3
gm
–2
·day
–1
, and the ionic conductivity for the solid electrolyte was measured in an air atmosphere. Even though Parylene has a high WVTR, and while ASH is found to be the most important layer in the TFE for the prevention of moisture permeation, the Parylene layer is absolutely necessary. It is revealed that the organic Parlyene layer restricts the interface formation between ASSTFBs and ASH during the ASH deposition process. The ASSTFBs with hybrid TFE consisting of ASH/Parylene were very stable even after completing 100 cycles over 30 days; they were not fully oxidized, and their capacity was 9.9 μAh cm
–2
μm
–1
even after 100 cycles. The Coulombic efficiency of ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs was estimated as high as 99.8%. From the results, the hybrid TFE is demonstrated to be suitable and effective for achieving the long-term stability of ASSTFBs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
The fabrication of ASSTFBs was a subject of a previously published paper in which the fabricating conditions and characteristics of the battery were confirmed in a glovebox.
(8)
Therefore, only the TFE results have been included in this paper. Polyimide was used as a substrate, Pt and Ti to be used as a current collector were deposited by a direct current (DC) sputter, and as a cathode, the LiFePO
4
thin film was fabricated by the off-axis sputtering method and crystallized by annealing at a 400 °C reducing gas atmosphere. The solid electrolyte LiPON was deposited by reactive sputtering with the Li
3
PO
4
target in an N
2
atmosphere and a thickness of 1.2 μm. As the anode current collector, NiCr-Ti was deposited by a DC sputter, and the Li metal for the anode thin film was grown by thermal evaporation.

To investigate each characteristic for thin films included in ASSTFBs, the TFE for ASSTFBs was fabricated with three different structures: Parylene/ASSTFBs, hybrid SiO
y
/SiN
x
O
y
/
a
-SiN
x
:H/ASSTFBs (ASH/ASSTFBs), and hybrid SiO
y
/SiN
x
O
y
/
a
-SiN
x
:H/Parylene/ASSTFBs (ASH/Parylene/ASSTFBs). The Parylene was fully deposited on the ASSTFBs. The deposition of the
a
-SiN
x
:H layer was carried out in a parallel plate capacitively coupled radio frequency (13.56 MHz) discharge PECVD system. The base pressure was maintained at 40 mTorr by a rotary and booster pump. The precursor gas for the deposition of
a
-SiN
x
:H films was a mixture of silane (SiH
4
), ammonia (NH
3
), and nitrogen (N
2
) as dilute gas at an optimized flow ratio of 25:100:380 cm

min
–1
. The deposition was performed at 120 °C for 8 min to obtain
a

x
:H films. Next, a hybrid SiO
y
/SiN
x
O
y
layer was formed on the
a

x
:H surface at a withdrawal speed of 3 mm s
–1
with a dip coater (EF-4200, E-Flex, Korea) after an immersion time of 5 min; the samples were then annealed at 120 °C for 10 h in an oven. During this annealing process, the ORMOSIL sol reacted with the

y
.
WVTR measurements were performed by using a commercial instrument, a MOCON Permatran W-700 and Aquatran 2 (PERMATRAN-W Model 700 and AQUATRAN Model 2, MOCON Inc., USA at 37.8 °C and 100% RH).

The electrochemical measurement of ASSTFBs encapsulated under all conditions was performed in an air atmosphere. The charge/discharge and cycle life measurement was carried out using an electrochemical measurement system (WBCS3000, Wonatech, Korea). The voltage range was approximately 3–4 V, and the current density was tested at a rate of 0.2 C. The theoretical capacity of LiFePO
4
was 170 mAh/g. The theoretical capacity of LiFePO
4
thin films, which was converted using the density of LiFePO
4
, was 61.13 μAh cm
–2
μm
–1
. The current corresponding to a rate of 0.2 C was 611 nA. The change of interfacial resistance was monitored by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS).

Utmost limits of various solid electrolytes in all-solid-state lithium batteries: A critical review

A review. All-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs) with solid electrolytes have attracted great attention for the replacement of traditional lithium batteries with liq. electrolytes due to their advantages such as high safety, excellent electrochem. cycling property and long-term stability. To date, various solid electrolytes including oxide, sulfide and polymer and org.-inorg. hybrid electrolytes have been developed for ASSLBs. Esp., the strategies to improve electrochem. performance esp. ionic cond. and stability of solid electrolytes have been widely studied. However, nowadays, ASSLBs are still not commercialized and used in our daily life. In this article, the situations of the solid electrolytes are critically reviewed, the main challenges and future prospective for the development of solid electrolytes are given and the utmost limits of those state-of-the-art solid electrolytes are analyzed. In addn., the electrode/electrolyte interface modification techniques to make ASSLBs achieving the excellent performance are evaluated. It is expected to provide a guidance for the development of novel solid electrolytes with higher ionic cond. and environmental stability for ASSLBs.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) continue to draw vast attention as a promising energy storage technol. due to their high energy d., low self-discharge property, nearly zero-memory effect, high open circuit voltage, and long lifespan. In particular, high-energy d. lithium-ion batteries are considered as the ideal power source for elec. vehicles (EVs) and hybrid elec. vehicles (HEVs) in the automotive industry, in recent years. This review discusses key aspects of the present and the future battery technologies on the basis of the working electrode. We then discuss how lithium-ion batteries evolve to meet the growing demand on high charge capacity and electrode stability. An account of a stand-alone energy device (off-grid system) that combines an energy harvesting technol. with a lithium-ion battery is also provided. The main discussion is categorized into three perspectives such as the evolution from the conventional to the advanced LIBs (e.g., Li-rich transition metal oxide and Ni-rich transition metal oxide batteries), to the state-of-the-art LIBs (e.g., Li-air, Li-sulfur batteries, org. electrode batteries, solid-state batteries, and Li-CO2 batteries), and to the hybridized LIBs (e.g., metal halide perovskite batteries).

All-solid-state (ASS) lithium-ion battery has attracted great attention due to its high safety and increased energy d. One of key components in the ASS battery (ASSB) is solid electrolyte that dets. performance of the ASSB. Many types of solid electrolytes have been investigated in great detail in the past years, including NASICON-type, garnet-type, perovskite-type, LISICON-type, LiPON-type, Li3N-type, sulfide-type, argyrodite-type, anti-perovskite-type and many more. This paper aims to provide comprehensive reviews on some typical types of key solid electrolytes and some ASSBs, and on gaps that should be resolved.

A review with 33 refs. Research over the last decade at Oak Ridge National Lab. has led to the development of solid-state thin-film lithium and lithium-ion batteries. The batteries, which are less than 15 μm thick, have important applications in a variety of consumer and medical products, and they are useful research tools in characterizing the properties of lithium intercalation compds. in thin-film form. The batteries consist of cathodes that are cryst. or nanocryst. oxide-based lithium intercalation compds. such as LiCoO2 and LiMn2O4, and anodes of lithium metal, inorg. compds. such as silicon-tin oxynitrides, Sn3N4 and Zn3N2, or metal films such as Cu in which the anode is formed by lithium plating on the initial charge. The electrolyte is a glassy lithium phosphorus oxynitride ("Lipon"). Cells with cryst. LiCoO2 cathodes can deliver up to 30% of their max. capacity between 4.2 and 3 V at discharge currents of 10 mA/cm2, and at more moderate discharge-charge rates, the capacity decreases by negligible amts. over thousands of cycles. Thin films of cryst. lithium manganese oxide with the general compn. Li1+xMn2-yO4 exhibit on the initial charge significant capacity at 5 V and, depending on the deposition process, at 4.6 V as well, as a consequence of the manganese deficiency-lithium excess. The 5-V plateau is believed to be due to oxidn. Mn of ions to valence states higher than +4 accompanied by a rearrangement of the lattice. The gap between the discharge-charge curves of cells with as-deposited nanocryst. Li1+xMn2-yO4 cathodes is due to a true hysteresis as opposed to a kinetically hindered relaxation obsd. with the highly cryst. films. This behavior was confirmed by observing classic scanning curves on charge and discharge at intermediate stages of insertion and extn. of Li+ ions. Extended cycling of lithium cells with these cathodes at 25 and 100°C leads to grain growth and evolution of the charge-discharge profiles toward those characteristic of well crystd. films.

A brief historical review on development of lithium-based thin-film rechargeable batteries including ongoing research strategies. The challenges that remain regarding the discovery of nanomaterials as electrolytes and electrodes for lithium batteries are discussed, the possible evolution of lithium technol. is described, and the expected improvements, arising from new materials to cell technol., are evaluated. New active materials under investigation and electrode process improvements may allow an ultimate final energy d. of >500 W-h/L and 200 W-h/kg, in the next 5-6 years, while maintaining sufficient power densities. A new rechargeable battery technol. cannot be foreseen today that surpasses this. This report provides key performance results for thin-film batteries and highlights recent advances in their development.

Thin-film solid-state rechargeable Li batteries are ideal micropower sources for many applications requiring high energy and power densities, good capacity retention for thousands of discharge/charge cycles, and an extremely low self-discharge rate. Batteries fabricated with cryst. LiCoO2 cathodes provide max. power levels up to 30 mW/cm2, have a long cycle life, negligible self-discharge and rapid charge rates. Promising results were also obtained with cryst. LiMn2O4 cathodes, although good reproducibility was not achieved. These fully lithiated cathodes can be used with Li-free or Li-ion thin-film anodes to produce batteries that can withstand high-temp. solder bonding processes.

Moitzheim, S.; Balder, J. E.; Ritasalo, R.; Ek, S.; Poodt, P.; Unnikrishnan, S.; De Gendt, S.; Vereecken, P. M.

Three-dimensional (3D) thin-film solid-state batteries are an interesting concept for microstorage, promising high footprint capacity, fast charging, safety, and long lifetime. However, to realize their commercialization, several challenges still need to be overcome. In this work, the focus is on two issues, the conformal coating and the high throughput deposition of thin-film layers. First, to facilitate conformal deposition, a design based on 3D micropillars is chosen. Although such a design has been suggested in the past, for the first time what (footprint) capacities can be expected when using fully optimized pillar geometries is calcd. while taking practical manufacturability into consideration. Next, spatial at. layer deposition (S-ALD) is investigated as a scalable and conformal deposition technique. As proof-of-concept, 100 nm Cl-doped am-TiO2 thin-film electrodes are deposited by S-ALD on TiN-coated silicon micropillars. The effect of deposition parameters (i.e., exposure time and temp.) on the conformality and uniformity across the micropillar substrate is investigated. The results are discussed in terms of precursor diffusion and depletion, which is supported by an anal. model developed for the micropillar array. Furthermore, the Li-ion insertion properties of 3D electrodes fabricated by S-ALD and conventional ALD are compared. This research highlights the challenges and promises of 3D microbatteries and guides future S-ALD development to enable conformal and high-throughput thin-film deposition.

The smart lens system is considered one of the ultimate wearable electronics platform, with potential applications in visual-guide or health-monitoring system. However, its development has so far been limited by the development of suitable flexible batteries. Conventional flexible battery fabrication relies on laser-based lift-off techniques, which greatly hinder scalability of such batteries. Here, we design and demonstrate the flexible thin film batteries applied to contact lens form-factor, with direct fabrication on polymer substrates and single step low-temp. annealing. The battery utilizes olivine LiFePO4 thin film cathode, fabricated with 90° off-axis sputter deposition. This achieves unique nanoscale microstructure required for electrochem. active LiFePO4 thin films and effectively reduces the annealing temp. of LiFePO4 down to 400°C for the first time. Equipped with lithium phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON) solid electrolyte and lithium metal anodes on polyimide substrates, the battery demonstrates the energy storage capacity of 35μWh under wet condition. The storage capacity is sufficient to power glucose sensors embedded on the smart lens for up to 11.7 h. In addn., the high energy d. of 70μWh/cm2 flexible batteries may enable a diverse set of micro-scale devices, with scalable and CMOS-compatible fabrication processes.

Solid-state electrolytes are attracting increasing interest for electrochem. energy storage technologies. In this Review, we provide a background overview and discuss the state of the art, ion-transport mechanisms and fundamental properties of solid-state electrolyte materials of interest for energy storage applications. We focus on recent advances in various classes of battery chemistries and systems that are enabled by solid electrolytes, including all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries and emerging solid-electrolyte lithium batteries that feature cathodes with liq. or gaseous active materials (for example, lithium-air, lithium-sulfur and lithium-bromine systems). A low-cost, safe, aq. electrochem. energy storage concept with a 'mediator-ion' solid electrolyte is also discussed. Advanced battery systems based on solid electrolytes would revitalize the rechargeable battery field because of their safety, excellent stability, long cycle lives and low cost. However, great effort will be needed to implement solid-electrolyte batteries as viable energy storage systems. In this context, we discuss the main issues that must be addressed, such as achieving acceptable ionic cond., electrochem. stability and mech. properties of the solid electrolytes, as well as a compatible electrolyte/electrode interface.

A review. The ever-increasing energy d. of the Li-ion battery calls for utilization of high-capacity cathodes and anodes, which tend to be more reactive and thus bring serious safety concern. Under such context, the solid-state Li battery becomes a hot-spot because of its potential in the breakthrough of energy d. as well as the avoidance of uncontrollable chem. reactions. Recently, many review and perspective papers appear, addressing the urgency of improving solid-electrolytes' ionic cond. and constructing stable conductive interfaces between electrolyte and electrode with respect to available electrolytes, including polymers, nitrides, sulfides, and oxides. Nevertheless, each type of electrolyte has its own distinctive problems, which is worthwhile specifically elaborating in order to find effective solns. Therefore, here, we present our viewpoints on the key issues related to the garnet electrolytes and relevant batteries, which have not ever been dedicatedly addressed previously. On the basis of our recent progress, together with others reported in the literature, we expect that the solid garnet batteries are promising for application if the best use is made of garnet advantages and disadvantages are bypassed.

Lithium phosphorus oxynitride (LiPON), the widely used solid electrolyte for thin-film microbatteries, is not compatible with the ambient humid temps. The reasons for redn. in ionic cond. of LiPON thin films from 2.8 × 10-6 S/cm to 9.9 × 10-10 S/cm when exposed to air are analyzed with the aid of a.c. impedance measurements, SEM, XPS and stylus profilometry. Initially, particulate-free film surfaces obtained soon after radio-frequency sputter deposition in N2 ambient conditions becomes covered with microstructures, forming pores in the film when exposed to air. LiPON films are deposited on Ti-coated silicon in addn. to bare silicon, ruling out the possibility of stress-related rupturing from the LiPON/Si interface. The redn. of nitrogen, phosphorus, and increased presence of lithium, oxygen and carbon over the film surface lowers the ionic cond. of LiPON films when exposed to air.

Development of all solid ceramic batteries was investigated in our research. Sintering process was one of the facile ways to construct all ceramic batteries. But the drawback was that the heat treatment of an active material layer and a solid electrolyte layer in contact with each other induced the solid-state reaction between them, resulting in electrochem. deactivation of the interface. When phosphate solid electrolytes such as Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP), and phosphate active materials such as LiCoPO4 and Li3Fe2(PO4)3 were selected, both the solid electrolyte layer and the active material layers could be co-sintered without significant formation of new materials, and the resulted interfaces were found to be electrochem. active.

Design of Highly Water Resistant, Impermeable, and Flexible Thin-Film Encapsulation Based on Inorganic/Organic Hybrid Layers
Kwon, Jeong Hyun; Jeong, Eun Gyo; Jeon, Yongmin; Kim, Do-Geun; Lee, Seunghun; Choi, Kyung Cheol
ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces
(
2019
),
11
(

3251-3261

; ISSN:
1944-8244
.

American Chemical Society
)
The lack of a transparent, flexible, and reliable encapsulation layer for org.-based devices makes it difficult to commercialize wearable, transparent, flexible displays. The reliability of org.-based devices sensitive to H2O vapor and O must be guaranteed through an addnl. encapsulation layer for the luminance efficiency and lifetime. Esp., one of the major difficulties in current and future OLED applications was the absence of thin-film encapsulation with superior barrier performance, mech. flexibility, and H2O-resistant properties. The authors fabricated highly H2O-resistant, impermeable, and flexible inorg./org. multilayers with optimized Al2O3 and functional org. layers. The key properties of the fabricated multilayers were compared according to the thickness and functionality of the inorg. and org. layers. Improvement of the barrier performance is mainly attributed to the optimized thickness of the Al2O3 films, and is addnl. due to the increased lag time and effective surface planarization effects caused using micrometer-thick org. layers. As a result, the 3-dyad multilayer structure composed of 60-nm-thick Al2O3 layers deposited at 70° and 2-μm-thick silane-based inorg./org. hybrid polymer (silamer) layers with layered SiO2 exhibited the lowest WVTR value of 1.11 × 10-6 g/m2/day in storage conditions of 30°/90% relative humidity. The multi-barrier exhibited good mech. stability through the use of alternating stacks of brittle inorg. and soft org. layers, without showing a large increase in the WVTR after bending tests. Silamer layers improved the environmental stability of the Al2O3 ALD film. The silamer layer coated on the Al2O3 film effectively worked as a protective layer against harsh environments. The effective contact at the interface of Al2O3/silamer makes the barrier structure more impermeable and corrosion-resistant. The authors not only demonstrated an optimized multilayer based on functional org. layers, but also provided a methodol. for designing a wearable encapsulation applicable to wearable org. electronics.

Org. optoelectronic devices, esp. for OLEDs, are extremely susceptibility to water vapor and oxygen which limit their widespread commercialization. In order to extend the shelf-lifetime of devices, thin film encapsulation is the most promising and challenging encapsulation process. In this study, dyad-style multilayer encapsulation structures based on alternating Al2O3 layer and parylene C have been discussed as gas diffusion barriers, in which dense and pinhole-free Al2O3 films were grown by at. layer deposition (ALD) and flexible parylene C layers were deposited by chem. vapor deposition (CVD). We found the particle in ALD deposited Al2O3 films process is the key killer to barrier property. The thickness of Al2O3 films is the key factor which limit the amt. of strain placed on barrier films. With three dyads of the optimal thickness of 30 nm Al2O3 film and 500 nm parylene C, WVTR value is lower than 10-5 g m-2 per day. In addn., the lifetime of OLEDs with and without encapsulation was 190 h and 10 h, resp. All the results show that this TFE structure has the effective encapsulated property and does not cause degrdn. of the OLED devices.

A review. This work presents recent achievements concerning thin film encapsulation of metallic lithium neg. electrode. In the context of this study, the encapsulation stack includes polymer and dielec. layers combined in such way to optimize barrier performances of the whole structure towards oxygen and water vapor permeation. The 1st part of this work is dedicated to the description of the barrier stack architecture and properties. A 2nd part presents the application of a microfabrication process to the metallic lithium neg. electrode and barrier stack so as to have very small features (100 μm × 100 μm patterns). The microfabrication process includes several steps of photolithog. and etching (dry and wet) blocks, which allows the authors to reach the target crit. dimensions. These results show a method of patterning functional metallic lithium. It demonstrates the feasibility of energy sources miniaturization which is an important issue in the field of autonomous and wireless sensor networks.

A review. Lithium microbatteries with different pos. electrode materials (V2O5, LiCoO2, TiOS) in assocn. with a solid electrolyte (LiPONB) and a lithium neg. electrode are very promising energy storage systems that can fit all the applications requirements. One of the challenges of the technol. is related to the fact that lithium microbatteries are easily degraded in atm. Indeed, these devices require encapsulation with a barrier material, which exhibits extremely low permeation rates for water vapor and oxygen. To obtain such a high barrier, the authors chose to direct their studies on layers deposited by plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition (PECVD), and more particularly on amorphous materials like silicon oxide (SiOx) and silicon nitride (SiNx). Both the active layers of the microbattery architecture and the multilayer encapsulation stack are discussed.

The application of micro electromech. systems (MEMS) technol. in several consumer electronics leads to the development of micro/nano power sources with high power and MEMS integration possibility. This work presents the fabrication of a flexible solid-state Li-ion battery (LIB) (∼2.1 μm thick) with a design towards electrodes elec. insulation, using conventional, low cost and compatible MEMS fabrication processes. Kapton substrate provides flexibility to the battery. E-beam deposited 300 nm thick Ge anode was coupled with LiCoO2/LiPON (cathode/solid-state electrolyte) in a battery system. LiCoO2 and LiPON films were deposited by RF-sputtering with a power source of 120 W and 100 W, resp. LiCoO2 film was annealed at 400 °C after deposition. The new design includes Si3N4 and LiPO thin-films, providing electrode elec. insulation and a battery chem. stability safeguard, resp. Microstructure and battery performance were investigated by SEM, elec. resistivity and electrochem. measurements (open circuit potential, charge/discharge cycles and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy). A rechargeable thin-film and lightwt. flexible LIB using MEMS processing compatible materials and techniques is reported.

Bending impact on the performance of a flexible Li4Ti5O12-based all-solid-state thin-film battery
Sepulveda, Alfonso; Speulmanns, Jan; Vereecken, Philippe M.

The growing demand of flexible electronic devices is increasing the requirements of their power sources. The effect of bending in thin-film batteries is still not well understood. Here, we successfully developed a high active area flexible all-solid-state battery as a model system that consists of thin-film layers of Li4Ti5O12, LiPON, and Lithium deposited on a novel flexible ceramic substrate. A systematic study on the bending state and performance of the battery is presented. The battery withstands bending radii of at least 14 mm achieving 70% of the theor. capacity. Here, we reveal that convex bending has a pos. effect on battery capacity showing an av. increase of 5.5%, whereas concave bending decreases the capacity by 4% in contrast with recent studies. We show that the change in capacity upon bending may well be assocd. to the Li-ion diffusion kinetic change through the electrode when different external forces are applied. Finally, an encapsulation scheme is presented allowing sufficient bending of the device and operation for at least 500 cycles in air. The results are meant to improve the understanding of the phenomena present in thin-film batteries while undergoing bending rather than showing improvements in battery performance and lifetime.

Negating interfacial impedance in garnet-based solid-state Li metal batteries
Han, Xiaogang; Gong, Yunhui; Fu, Kun; He, Xingfeng; Hitz, Gregory T.; Dai, Jiaqi; Pearse, Alex; Liu, Boyang; Wang, Howard; Rubloff, Gary; Mo, Yifei; Thangadurai, Venkataraman; Wachsman, Eric D.; Hu, Liangbing

Garnet-type solid-state electrolytes have attracted extensive attention due to their high ionic cond., approaching 1 mS cm-1, excellent environmental stability, and wide electrochem. stability window, from lithium metal to ∼6 V. However, to date, there has been little success in the development of high-performance solid-state batteries using these exceptional materials, the major challenge being the high solid-solid interfacial impedance between the garnet electrolyte and electrode materials. In this work, we effectively address the large interfacial impedance between a lithium metal anode and the garnet electrolyte using ultrathin aluminum oxide (Al2O3) by at. layer deposition. Li7La2.75Ca0.25Zr1.75Nb0.25O12 (LLCZN) is the garnet compn. of choice in this work due to its reduced sintering temp. and increased lithium ion cond. A significant decrease of interfacial impedance, from 1,710 Ω cm2 to 1 Ω cm2, was obsd. at room temp., effectively negating the lithium metal/garnet interfacial impedance. Exptl. and computational results reveal that the oxide coating enables wetting of metallic lithium in contact with the garnet electrolyte surface and the lithiated-alumina interface allows effective lithium ion transport between the lithium metal anode and garnet electrolyte. We also demonstrate a working cell with a lithium metal anode, garnet electrolyte and a high-voltage cathode by applying the newly developed interface chem.

Utmost limits of various solid electrolytes in all-solid-state lithium batteries: A critical review
Wu, Zhijun; Xie, Zhengkun; Yoshida, Akihiro; Wang, Zhongde; Hao, Xiaogang; Abudula, Abuliti; Guan, Guoqing

A review. All-solid-state lithium batteries (ASSLBs) with solid electrolytes have attracted great attention for the replacement of traditional lithium batteries with liq. electrolytes due to their advantages such as high safety, excellent electrochem. cycling property and long-term stability. To date, various solid electrolytes including oxide, sulfide and polymer and org.-inorg. hybrid electrolytes have been developed for ASSLBs. Esp., the strategies to improve electrochem. performance esp. ionic cond. and stability of solid electrolytes have been widely studied. However, nowadays, ASSLBs are still not commercialized and used in our daily life. In this article, the situations of the solid electrolytes are critically reviewed, the main challenges and future prospective for the development of solid electrolytes are given and the utmost limits of those state-of-the-art solid electrolytes are analyzed. In addn., the electrode/electrolyte interface modification techniques to make ASSLBs achieving the excellent performance are evaluated. It is expected to provide a guidance for the development of novel solid electrolytes with higher ionic cond. and environmental stability for ASSLBs.

Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) continue to draw vast attention as a promising energy storage technol. due to their high energy d., low self-discharge property, nearly zero-memory effect, high open circuit voltage, and long lifespan. In particular, high-energy d. lithium-ion batteries are considered as the ideal power source for elec. vehicles (EVs) and hybrid elec. vehicles (HEVs) in the automotive industry, in recent years. This review discusses key aspects of the present and the future battery technologies on the basis of the working electrode. We then discuss how lithium-ion batteries evolve to meet the growing demand on high charge capacity and electrode stability. An account of a stand-alone energy device (off-grid system) that combines an energy harvesting technol. with a lithium-ion battery is also provided. The main discussion is categorized into three perspectives such as the evolution from the conventional to the advanced LIBs (e.g., Li-rich transition metal oxide and Ni-rich transition metal oxide batteries), to the state-of-the-art LIBs (e.g., Li-air, Li-sulfur batteries, org. electrode batteries, solid-state batteries, and Li-CO2 batteries), and to the hybridized LIBs (e.g., metal halide perovskite batteries).

All-solid-state (ASS) lithium-ion battery has attracted great attention due to its high safety and increased energy d. One of key components in the ASS battery (ASSB) is solid electrolyte that dets. performance of the ASSB. Many types of solid electrolytes have been investigated in great detail in the past years, including NASICON-type, garnet-type, perovskite-type, LISICON-type, LiPON-type, Li3N-type, sulfide-type, argyrodite-type, anti-perovskite-type and many more. This paper aims to provide comprehensive reviews on some typical types of key solid electrolytes and some ASSBs, and on gaps that should be resolved.

A review with 33 refs. Research over the last decade at Oak Ridge National Lab. has led to the development of solid-state thin-film lithium and lithium-ion batteries. The batteries, which are less than 15 μm thick, have important applications in a variety of consumer and medical products, and they are useful research tools in characterizing the properties of lithium intercalation compds. in thin-film form. The batteries consist of cathodes that are cryst. or nanocryst. oxide-based lithium intercalation compds. such as LiCoO2 and LiMn2O4, and anodes of lithium metal, inorg. compds. such as silicon-tin oxynitrides, Sn3N4 and Zn3N2, or metal films such as Cu in which the anode is formed by lithium plating on the initial charge. The electrolyte is a glassy lithium phosphorus oxynitride ("Lipon"). Cells with cryst. LiCoO2 cathodes can deliver up to 30% of their max. capacity between 4.2 and 3 V at discharge currents of 10 mA/cm2, and at more moderate discharge-charge rates, the capacity decreases by negligible amts. over thousands of cycles. Thin films of cryst. lithium manganese oxide with the general compn. Li1+xMn2-yO4 exhibit on the initial charge significant capacity at 5 V and, depending on the deposition process, at 4.6 V as well, as a consequence of the manganese deficiency-lithium excess. The 5-V plateau is believed to be due to oxidn. Mn of ions to valence states higher than +4 accompanied by a rearrangement of the lattice. The gap between the discharge-charge curves of cells with as-deposited nanocryst. Li1+xMn2-yO4 cathodes is due to a true hysteresis as opposed to a kinetically hindered relaxation obsd. with the highly cryst. films. This behavior was confirmed by observing classic scanning curves on charge and discharge at intermediate stages of insertion and extn. of Li+ ions. Extended cycling of lithium cells with these cathodes at 25 and 100°C leads to grain growth and evolution of the charge-discharge profiles toward those characteristic of well crystd. films.

A brief historical review on development of lithium-based thin-film rechargeable batteries including ongoing research strategies. The challenges that remain regarding the discovery of nanomaterials as electrolytes and electrodes for lithium batteries are discussed, the possible evolution of lithium technol. is described, and the expected improvements, arising from new materials to cell technol., are evaluated. New active materials under investigation and electrode process improvements may allow an ultimate final energy d. of >500 W-h/L and 200 W-h/kg, in the next 5-6 years, while maintaining sufficient power densities. A new rechargeable battery technol. cannot be foreseen today that surpasses this. This report provides key performance results for thin-film batteries and highlights recent advances in their development.

Thin-film solid-state rechargeable Li batteries are ideal micropower sources for many applications requiring high energy and power densities, good capacity retention for thousands of discharge/charge cycles, and an extremely low self-discharge rate. Batteries fabricated with cryst. LiCoO2 cathodes provide max. power levels up to 30 mW/cm2, have a long cycle life, negligible self-discharge and rapid charge rates. Promising results were also obtained with cryst. LiMn2O4 cathodes, although good reproducibility was not achieved. These fully lithiated cathodes can be used with Li-free or Li-ion thin-film anodes to produce batteries that can withstand high-temp. solder bonding processes.

Three-dimensional (3D) thin-film solid-state batteries are an interesting concept for microstorage, promising high footprint capacity, fast charging, safety, and long lifetime. However, to realize their commercialization, several challenges still need to be overcome. In this work, the focus is on two issues, the conformal coating and the high throughput deposition of thin-film layers. First, to facilitate conformal deposition, a design based on 3D micropillars is chosen. Although such a design has been suggested in the past, for the first time what (footprint) capacities can be expected when using fully optimized pillar geometries is calcd. while taking practical manufacturability into consideration. Next, spatial at. layer deposition (S-ALD) is investigated as a scalable and conformal deposition technique. As proof-of-concept, 100 nm Cl-doped am-TiO2 thin-film electrodes are deposited by S-ALD on TiN-coated silicon micropillars. The effect of deposition parameters (i.e., exposure time and temp.) on the conformality and uniformity across the micropillar substrate is investigated. The results are discussed in terms of precursor diffusion and depletion, which is supported by an anal. model developed for the micropillar array. Furthermore, the Li-ion insertion properties of 3D electrodes fabricated by S-ALD and conventional ALD are compared. This research highlights the challenges and promises of 3D microbatteries and guides future S-ALD development to enable conformal and high-throughput thin-film deposition.

The smart lens system is considered one of the ultimate wearable electronics platform, with potential applications in visual-guide or health-monitoring system. However, its development has so far been limited by the development of suitable flexible batteries. Conventional flexible battery fabrication relies on laser-based lift-off techniques, which greatly hinder scalability of such batteries. Here, we design and demonstrate the flexible thin film batteries applied to contact lens form-factor, with direct fabrication on polymer substrates and single step low-temp. annealing. The battery utilizes olivine LiFePO4 thin film cathode, fabricated with 90° off-axis sputter deposition. This achieves unique nanoscale microstructure required for electrochem. active LiFePO4 thin films and effectively reduces the annealing temp. of LiFePO4 down to 400°C for the first time. Equipped with lithium phosphorous oxynitride (LiPON) solid electrolyte and lithium metal anodes on polyimide substrates, the battery demonstrates the energy storage capacity of 35μWh under wet condition. The storage capacity is sufficient to power glucose sensors embedded on the smart lens for up to 11.7 h. In addn., the high energy d. of 70μWh/cm2 flexible batteries may enable a diverse set of micro-scale devices, with scalable and CMOS-compatible fabrication processes.

Solid-state electrolytes are attracting increasing interest for electrochem. energy storage technologies. In this Review, we provide a background overview and discuss the state of the art, ion-transport mechanisms and fundamental properties of solid-state electrolyte materials of interest for energy storage applications. We focus on recent advances in various classes of battery chemistries and systems that are enabled by solid electrolytes, including all-solid-state lithium-ion batteries and emerging solid-electrolyte lithium batteries that feature cathodes with liq. or gaseous active materials (for example, lithium-air, lithium-sulfur and lithium-bromine systems). A low-cost, safe, aq. electrochem. energy storage concept with a 'mediator-ion' solid electrolyte is also discussed. Advanced battery systems based on solid electrolytes would revitalize the rechargeable battery field because of their safety, excellent stability, long cycle lives and low cost. However, great effort will be needed to implement solid-electrolyte batteries as viable energy storage systems. In this context, we discuss the main issues that must be addressed, such as achieving acceptable ionic cond., electrochem. stability and mech. properties of the solid electrolytes, as well as a compatible electrolyte/electrode interface.

A review. The ever-increasing energy d. of the Li-ion battery calls for utilization of high-capacity cathodes and anodes, which tend to be more reactive and thus bring serious safety concern. Under such context, the solid-state Li battery becomes a hot-spot because of its potential in the breakthrough of energy d. as well as the avoidance of uncontrollable chem. reactions. Recently, many review and perspective papers appear, addressing the urgency of improving solid-electrolytes' ionic cond. and constructing stable conductive interfaces between electrolyte and electrode with respect to available electrolytes, including polymers, nitrides, sulfides, and oxides. Nevertheless, each type of electrolyte has its own distinctive problems, which is worthwhile specifically elaborating in order to find effective solns. Therefore, here, we present our viewpoints on the key issues related to the garnet electrolytes and relevant batteries, which have not ever been dedicatedly addressed previously. On the basis of our recent progress, together with others reported in the literature, we expect that the solid garnet batteries are promising for application if the best use is made of garnet advantages and disadvantages are bypassed.

Lithium phosphorus oxynitride (LiPON), the widely used solid electrolyte for thin-film microbatteries, is not compatible with the ambient humid temps. The reasons for redn. in ionic cond. of LiPON thin films from 2.8 × 10-6 S/cm to 9.9 × 10-10 S/cm when exposed to air are analyzed with the aid of a.c. impedance measurements, SEM, XPS and stylus profilometry. Initially, particulate-free film surfaces obtained soon after radio-frequency sputter deposition in N2 ambient conditions becomes covered with microstructures, forming pores in the film when exposed to air. Development of all solid ceramic batteries was investigated in our research. Sintering process was one of the facile ways to construct all ceramic batteries. But the drawback was that the heat treatment of an active material layer and a solid electrolyte layer in contact with each other induced the solid-state reaction between them, resulting in electrochem. deactivation of the interface. When phosphate solid electrolytes such as Li1.3Al0.3Ti1.7(PO4)3 (LATP), and phosphate active materials such as LiCoPO4 and Li3Fe2(PO4)3 were selected, both the solid electrolyte layer and the active material layers could be co-sintered without significant formation of new materials, and the resulted interfaces were found to be electrochem. active.

The lack of a transparent, flexible, and reliable encapsulation layer for org.-based devices makes it difficult to commercialize wearable, transparent, flexible displays. The reliability of org.-based devices sensitive to H2O vapor and O must be guaranteed through an addnl. encapsulation layer for the luminance efficiency and lifetime. Esp., one of the major difficulties in current and future OLED applications was the absence of thin-film encapsulation with superior barrier performance, mech. flexibility, and H2O-resistant properties. The authors fabricated highly H2O-resistant, impermeable, and flexible inorg./org. multilayers with optimized Al2O3 and functional org. layers. The key properties of the fabricated multilayers were compared according to the thickness and functionality of the inorg. and org. layers. Improvement of the barrier performance is mainly attributed to the optimized thickness of the Al2O3 films, and is addnl. due to the increased lag time and effective surface planarization effects caused using micrometer-thick org. layers. As a result, the 3-dyad multilayer structure composed of 60-nm-thick Al2O3 layers deposited at 70° and 2-μm-thick silane-based inorg./org. hybrid polymer (silamer) layers with layered SiO2 exhibited the lowest WVTR value of 1.11 × 10-6 g/m2/day in storage conditions of 30°/90% relative humidity. The multi-barrier exhibited good mech. stability through the use of alternating stacks of brittle inorg. and soft org. layers, without showing a large increase in the WVTR after bending tests. Silamer layers improved the environmental stability of the Al2O3 ALD film. The silamer layer coated on the Al2O3 film effectively worked as a protective layer against harsh environments. The effective contact at the interface of Al2O3/silamer makes the barrier structure more impermeable and corrosion-resistant. The authors not only demonstrated an optimized multilayer based on functional org. layers, but also provided a methodol. for designing a wearable encapsulation applicable to wearable org. electronics.

Wu, Jie; Fei, Fei; Wei, Changting; Chen, Xiaolian; Nie, Shuhong; Zhang, Dongyu; Su, Wenming; Cui, Zheng
RSC Advances
(

(

CODEN:

Royal Society of Chemistry

Org. optoelectronic devices, esp. for OLEDs, are extremely susceptibility to water vapor and oxygen which limit their widespread commercialization. In order to extend the shelf-lifetime of devices, thin film encapsulation is the most promising and challenging encapsulation process. In this study, dyad-style multilayer encapsulation structures based on alternating Al2O3 layer and parylene C have been discussed as gas diffusion barriers, in which dense and pinhole-free Al2O3 films were grown by at. layer deposition (ALD) and flexible parylene C layers were deposited by chem. vapor deposition (CVD). We found the particle in ALD deposited Al2O3 films process is the key killer to barrier property. The thickness of Al2O3 films is the key factor which limit the amt. of strain placed on barrier films. With three dyads of the optimal thickness of 30 nm Al2O3 film and 500 nm parylene C, WVTR value is lower than 10-5 g m-2 per day. In addn., the lifetime of OLEDs with and without encapsulation was 190 h and 10 h, resp. All the results show that this TFE structure has the effective encapsulated property and does not cause degrdn. of the OLED devices.

A review. This work presents recent achievements concerning thin film encapsulation of metallic lithium neg. electrode. In the context of this study, the encapsulation stack includes polymer and dielec. layers combined in such way to optimize barrier performances of the whole structure towards oxygen and water vapor permeation. The 1st part of this work is dedicated to the description of the barrier stack architecture and properties. A 2nd part presents the application of a microfabrication process to the metallic lithium neg. electrode and barrier stack so as to have very small features (100 μm × 100 μm patterns). The microfabrication process includes several steps of photolithog. and etching (dry and wet) blocks, which allows the authors to reach the target crit. dimensions. These results show a method of patterning functional metallic lithium. It demonstrates the feasibility of energy sources miniaturization which is an important issue in the field of autonomous and wireless sensor networks.

A review. Lithium microbatteries with different pos. electrode materials (V2O5, LiCoO2, TiOS) in assocn. with a solid electrolyte (LiPONB) and a lithium neg. electrode are very promising energy storage systems that can fit all the applications requirements. One of the challenges of the technol. is related to the fact that lithium microbatteries are easily degraded in atm. Indeed, these devices require encapsulation with a barrier material, which exhibits extremely low permeation rates for water vapor and oxygen. To obtain such a high barrier, the authors chose to direct their studies on layers deposited by plasma-enhanced chem. vapor deposition (PECVD), and more particularly on amorphous materials like silicon oxide (SiOx) and silicon nitride (SiNx). Both the active layers of the microbattery architecture and the multilayer encapsulation stack are discussed.

A flexible Li-ion battery with design towards electrodes electrical insulation
Vieira, E. M. F.; Ribeiro, J. F.; Sousa, R.; Correia, J. H.; Goncalves, L. M.

The application of micro electromech. systems (MEMS) technol. in several consumer electronics leads to the development of micro/nano power sources with high power and MEMS integration possibility. This work presents the fabrication of a flexible solid-state Li-ion battery (LIB) (∼2.1 μm thick) with a design towards electrodes elec. insulation, using conventional, low cost and compatible MEMS fabrication processes. Kapton substrate provides flexibility to the battery. E-beam deposited 300 nm thick Ge anode was coupled with LiCoO2/LiPON (cathode/solid-state electrolyte) in a battery system. LiCoO2 and LiPON films were deposited by RF-sputtering with a power source of 120 W and 100 W, resp. LiCoO2 film was annealed at 400 °C after deposition. The new design includes Si3N4 and LiPO thin-films, providing electrode elec. insulation and a battery chem. stability safeguard, resp. Microstructure and battery performance were investigated by SEM, elec. resistivity and electrochem. measurements (open circuit potential, charge/discharge cycles and electrochem. impedance spectroscopy). A rechargeable thin-film and lightwt. flexible LIB using MEMS processing compatible materials and techniques is reported.

Bending impact on the performance of a flexible Li4Ti5O12-based all-solid-state thin-film battery
Sepulveda, Alfonso; Speulmanns, Jan; Vereecken, Philippe M.
Science and Technology of Advanced Materials
(
2018
),

CODEN:

The growing demand of flexible electronic devices is increasing the requirements of their power sources. The effect of bending in thin-film batteries is still not well understood. Here, we successfully developed a high active area flexible all-solid-state battery as a model system that consists of thin-film layers of Li4Ti5O12, LiPON, and Lithium deposited on a novel flexible ceramic substrate. A systematic study on the bending state and performance of the battery is presented. The battery withstands bending radii of at least 14 mm achieving 70% of the theor. capacity. Here, we reveal that convex bending has a pos. effect on battery capacity showing an av. increase of 5.5%, whereas concave bending decreases the capacity by 4% in contrast with recent studies. We show that the change in capacity upon bending may well be assocd. to the Li-ion diffusion kinetic change through the electrode when different external forces are applied. Finally, an encapsulation scheme is presented allowing sufficient bending of the device and operation for at least 500 cycles in air. The results are meant to improve the understanding of the phenomena present in thin-film batteries while undergoing bending rather than showing improvements in battery performance and lifetime.

Negating interfacial impedance in garnet-based solid-state Li metal batteries
Han, Xiaogang; Gong, Yunhui; Fu, Kun; He, Xingfeng; Hitz, Gregory T.; Dai, Jiaqi; Pearse, Alex; Liu, Boyang; Wang, Howard; Rubloff, Gary; Mo, Yifei; Thangadurai, Venkataraman; Wachsman, Eric D.; Hu, Liangbing

(

CODEN:

; ISSN:
1476-1122
.

Nature Publishing Group
)
Garnet-type solid-state electrolytes have attracted extensive attention due to their high ionic cond., approaching 1 mS cm-1, excellent environmental stability, and wide electrochem. stability window, from lithium metal to ∼6 V. However, to date, there has been little success in the development of high-performance solid-state batteries using these exceptional materials, the major challenge being the high solid-solid interfacial impedance between the garnet electrolyte and electrode materials. In this work, we effectively address the large interfacial impedance between a lithium metal anode and the garnet electrolyte using ultrathin aluminum oxide (Al2O3) by at. layer deposition. Li7La2.75Ca0.25Zr1.75Nb0.25O12 (LLCZN) is the garnet compn. of choice in this work due to its reduced sintering temp. and increased lithium ion cond. A significant decrease of interfacial impedance, from 1,710 Ω cm2 to 1 Ω cm2, was obsd. at room temp., effectively negating the lithium metal/garnet interfacial impedance. Exptl. and computational results reveal that the oxide coating enables wetting of metallic lithium in contact with the garnet electrolyte surface and the lithiated-alumina interface allows effective lithium ion transport between the lithium metal anode and garnet electrolyte. We also demonstrate a working cell with a lithium metal anode, garnet electrolyte and a high-voltage cathode by applying the newly developed interface chem.
